dataset.title: Height of Dominant Woody Plants Inside and Outside Exclosures Located in FP1

address.deliveryPoint: Institute of Arctic Biology University of Alaska Fairbanks P.O. Box 757000
Institute of Arctic Biology University of Alaska Fairbanks P.O. Box 757000
Institute of Arctic Biology University of Alaska Fairbanks P.O. Box 757000

abstract.para: This study examines the effects browsing by mammals has on the function of the Alaskan taiga ecosystem. The primary emphasis is on the effects of browsing in winter by snowshoe hares (Lepus americanus) and moose (Alces alces) have on primary succession on the floodplain of the Tannana River. On this floodplain exclosures established in the willow stage and alder stage of succession in 1988 have been used to evaluate the effect of browsing has had on vegetation dynamics, element cycling, soil chemistry. Additionally, the effect on vegetation type on the diversity and abundance of neotropical birds nesting on the the Tannana floodplain has been examinedand insects. This ongoing study has been in progress for 10 years.

section.title: Access to Data
section.para: While metadata will be freely available to those requesting it, the data manager will assure that any restrictions on access to data sets in the database will be enforced. Data will not be released without proper permission first being obtained from the investigator who generated the data.

section.title: Use of data
section.para: Researchers should receive adequate acknowledgment for the use of their data by others and should be provided with copies of publications using their data. Users of data from the data base must be aware that data is not to be sold or redistributed.

section.title: Citing Bonanza Creek LTER Datasets
section.para: It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set.

section.title: corrections
section.para: These data are part of a two-stage sampling protocol. In the first stage, several attributes of all ramets occurring in permanent quadrats are recorded. Because (1) the probability of including dominant plants in a quadrat is low for all species sampled, and (2) because these dominant plants have a disproportionate effect on ecosystem processes such as browse production and litter production, the second stage of sampling considered dominant plants irrespective of their occurrence in or out of permanent quadrats. This data set provides the heights of these dominant plants from 1988 - 1998.

section.title: Experimental Design
section.para: Exclosures were established at all sites on the floodplain of the Tannana River within the Bonanza Creek LTER site that were large enough to contain at least one 30m x 30m exclosure and its associated 30m X 30m control site. Nine such exclosures were established in 1988; 4 at the A site, 3 at the C site, and 2 at the B site. By 1994, 2 of the exclosures at the A site had been washed out by the river, so only 7 exclosures remain at this time. The exclosures were of two types. One included both the willow stage of succession and the alder stage of succession. This type of exclosure was 50m by 20m rectangle oriented perpendicular to the interface between willow stage and alder stage of succession. The other type of exclosure was 20m x 20m in dimension and was located entirely within the willow stage of succession. Within these exclosures permanent 2m x 1m quadrats were located randomly within 4m wide strata. In the case of the larger exclosures these strata were oriented parallel to the alder/willow interface. In the case of the smaller exclosures the strata were oriented parallel to the river. All sampling used this stratified random sampling design.

section.title: Methods
section.para: In each of 7 exclosures and their respective control plots, 5 dominant individuals of each of 7 woody species (Salix alaxensis, S. brachycarpa, S. interior, S. lasiandra, S. nova-anglae, Populus balsamifera, Alnus tenuifolia) were randomly selected. A member of a species was considered to be dominant if it was among the 25 largest individuals of that species in the exclosure and respective control plot. These 25 dominant individuals of each species were numbered, and a random number generator was used to select the 5 individuals of each species to be examined each year from 1988 - 1998. The largest ramet of each individual was tagged, and the height of each tagged ramet was measured in late May each year from 1988 - 1998. Additionally, whether each ramet was live or dead was recorded. If a ramet was dead, then the height was recorded as zero.

dataTable.entityDescription: 1988-1998 data Height of Dominant Woody Plants Inside and Outside Exclosures Located in FP1.
